column1: County Louth ( Irish: Contae Lú) is a county in the Republic of Ireland. It is in the province of Leinster and is part of the Mid-East Region. It is named after the village of Louth. Louth County Council is the local authority for the county. According to the 2016 census
column2: the population of the county was 128

column1: County Louth is colloquially known as 'the Wee County' as it is Ireland's smallest county by area (826 km2 319 mi2). It is the 18th-largest in terms of population. It is the smallest of Leinster's 12 counties by size and the sixth-largest by population.
With its fairly average total population and its small size
column2: Louth is the second-most densely populated county in Ireland
column4: and the fourth-most on the island of Ireland.

column1: County Louth is named after the village of Louth
column2: which in turn is named after Lugh
column3: a god of the ancient Irish. Historically
column4: the placename has had various spellings; "Lugmad"
column7: for full listing). Lú is the modern simplified spelling.

column1: The county is steeped in myth
column3: and is a setting in the Táin Bó Cúailnge. Later it saw the influence of the Vikings
column4: as seen in the name of Carlingford Lough. They also established a longphort at Annagassan in the ninth century. At this time Louth consisted of three sub-kingdoms
column5: each subject to separate over-kingdoms: Conaille (Ulaidh); Fir Rois (Airgialla); and
column6: the Fir Arda Ciannachta (Midhe). The whole area became part of the O'Carroll Kingdom of Airgialla (Oriel) early in the 12th century under Donnchad Ua Cerbaill. At the same time
column7: the area was removed from the diocese of Armagh and the episcopal see of the Diocese of Airgíalla or Clogher was transferred to Louth c. 1130–1190.

column1: A number of historic sites are in the county
column3: Mellifont Abbey and the St Mary Magdalene Dominican Friary.

column1: The Normans occupied the Louth area in the 1180s
column2: and it became known as 'English' Oriel
column3: to distinguish it from the remainder ('Irish' Oriel) which remained in Irish hands. The latter became the McMahon lordship of Oriel of County Monaghan.

column1: In the early 14th century Edward Bruce made claim to the High Kingship of Ireland and led a expeditionary force to Ireland. The Scottish army was repulsed from Drogheda but laid waste to much of the Anglo-Norman colony of Ireland. Edward was crowned near Dundalk on the hill of Maledon on 2 May 1316. His army was finally defeated and Edward killed in the Battle of Faughart near Dundalk
column2: by a chiefly local force led by John de Bermingham.
a royal charter was granted to Dundalk after a Norman nobleman named Bertram de Verdun erected a manor house at Castletown Mount. Later in 1412
column3: a royal charter was granted to Drogheda. This charter unified the towns of Drogheda-in-Meath and Drogheda-in-Uriel (Louth) as a County in its own right
column4: styled as ‘the County of the town of Drogheda’. Drogheda continued as a County Borough until the setting up of County Councils
column5: through the enactment of the Local Government (Ireland) Act 1898
column7: including a large area south of the River Boyne
column8: become part of an extended County Louth.Until the late 16th century
column9: Louth had been a part of Ulster
column10: before being included as part of Leinster after a conference held at Faughart (in 1596) between the Chiefs of Ulster (O'Nial/O'Niel and O'Donel/O'Donnell)
column12: and the Archbishop of Cashel and the Earl of Ormonde on that of the English.

column1: The 16th and 17th centuries featured many skirmishes and battles involving Irish and English forces
column2: as Louth was on the main route to 'the Moiry Pass' and the Ulster areas often in rebellion and as yet uncolonised. Oliver Cromwell attacked Drogheda in 1649 slaughtering the Royalist garrison and hundreds of the town's citizens. Towards the end of the same century
column3: the armies of the warring Kings
column4: James II and William (III) of Orange
column5: faced off in south Louth during the build-up to the Battle of the Boyne; the battle was fought 3 km west from Drogheda. Drogheda held for James under Lord Iveagh
column6: but surrendered to William the day after the battle of the Boyne.In 1798
column7: the leaders of the United Irishmen included Bartholomew Teeling
column10: all from Castletown; Anthony Marmion from Louth Town and Dundalk
column11: Anthony McCann from Corderry; Nicholas and Thomas Markey from Barmeath
column14: and James McAllister from Cambricville. They were betrayed by informers
column17: and an agent provocateur called Sam Turner
column18: from Newry. Several leaders were hanged.

column1: The priest and scientist Nicholas Callan (1799–1864) was from Darver.
County Louth is the 18th largest county in terms of population
column2: but it is the most densely populated county in Ireland outside Dublin
column3: with a population density of 160 people per km2
column4: almost double the national average. The majority of the county's population lives in the two main towns of Drogheda and Dundalk
column5: also the overall 6th- and 8th-largest urban areas in Ireland respectively.

column1: The local authority is Louth County Council
column3: which provides a number of services including planning

column11: County Louth has been subdivided into four Local Electoral Areas (often abbreviated as LEA) for elections to Louth County Council and three Municipal districts for local government

column2: Louth is represented by the five member Louth constituency which takes in the entire county of Louth and two electoral divisions in County Meath.

column1: the Electoral (Amendment) Act 2009 merged the electoral divisions of St.Mary's (Part) and Julianstown
column2: collectively known as "East Meath" in County Meath with County Louth to form one Louth Dáil constituency.

column1: The Report on Dáil and European Parliament Constituencies 2007 outlined;"by extending the constituency southwards from
column3: Drogheda and taking in electoral divisions which have extensive linkages with the town. This will allow the inclusion of the town of Drogheda and hinterland areas in a single constituency." This merger allowed the areas of the Greater Drogheda area in County Meath and their combined population of 20
column4: 375 to be merged with Drogheda and County Louth.

column2: the constituency elected two TDs for the Fine Gael party (centre right)
column3: and one TD each for Fianna Fáil (centre to centre-right)
column4: the Labour Party (centre left) and Sinn Féin (left wing).
